awd_titl_txt: Quantitative and Qualitative properties of solutions of partial differential equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposal is concerned with the analysis and applications of nonlinear partial differential equations. The model problems in this proposal arise from the study of various nonlinear phenomena and other scientific disciplines, including condensed matter physics, elasticity, inverse problem, electrodynamics, quantum mechanics, fluid mechanics, mathematics biology, differential geometry, etc. The focus of the proposal research is the investigation of the quantitative and qualitative properties of solutions for partial differential equations. Providing quantitative and qualitative information for the solutions is fundamental and essential in the study of partial differential equations, which lies in the core of mathematical analysis. It is often the case that the most effective and economical way in scientific research is to explore properties of solutions and then to develop algorithm in accordance. Besides being very useful in applied science, the investigation of various kinds of structures and properties of solutions for various types of equations absolutely leads to new theories in  mathematics.

The proposed projects include quantitative uniqueness, eigenfunction and eigenvalue estimates, as well as Liouville-type theorems. Techniques and ideas from analysis area, such as elliptic estimates and Fourier analysis, will be combined and applied into this project. The proposed research should enhance the understanding of classical and Steklov eigenvalue problems, semilinear and higher order elliptic equations, wave equations, fractional Laplacians, fully nonlinear equations, etc.  Further research will be devoted to the study of quantitative uniqueness of parabolic differential equations and other important equations from mathematical physics.  Another related direction is the study of phase separations phenomenon in Bose-Einstein condensate. Emphasis will be placed on the two components Gross-Pitaevskki system.  An important part of proposed research is on eigenfunction and eigenvalue estimates. Techniques and insights in the various areas cross-fertilize  each other in a fruitful way in this area. The topics consist of measure of nodal sets (zero level sets),  asymptotic behavior of eigenvalues, Lebesgue norm estimates, as well as  doubling estimates of Steklov eigenfunctions and classical eigenfunctions.  Much effort will be made towards Yau's conjecture asserting that the size of nodal sets is comparable to its frequency. The principal investigator will also continue the previous investigation on Liouville-type theorems on nonexistence of solutions for fractional Laplacian equations and fully nonlinear partial differential equations.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to study quantitative and qualitative properties of solutions of partial differential equations. The efforts in this project period is devoted to the investigation concerning quantitative uniqueness of elliptic equations as well as eigenfunction and eigenvalue estimates. Techniques and ideas in different analysis areas are combined and applied into this project due to the complexity of problems. Providing quantitative and qualitative information for the solutions is fundamental and essential in the study of partial differential equations, which lies in the core of mathematical analysis.

Intellectual merit: 1,  The eigenvalue and eigenfunction problems are archetypical in the theory of elliptic equations. The understanding of any useful properties for eigenfunctions and eigenvalues contributes to the basic knowledge of partial differential equations. The PI has made substantial contributions to the Hausdorff measure of nodal sets of Steklov eigenfunctions The PI has also done interesting works on nodal sets of Robin eigenfunctions and bi-Laplacian.

2, The PI studied quantitative uniqueness to elliptic and parabolic PDEs. Quantitative uniqueness, a recent fast developing area, describes quantitative behavior of strong unique continuation property. The PI has obtained rich  results for quantitative uniqueness of solutions to semilinear elliptic and parabolic PDEs, as well as higher order elliptic PDEs. Some new ideas and approach have been applied in studying this topic.

Broader Impact: 1, The PI has been actively engaged in activities to make contributions to the mathematical community. The PI co-organized three special sessions  AMS meeting from 2017 to 2018 and ones special session of AMS joint mathematical meeting  in 2018. Graduate students and young postdoctoral researchers, especially women and underrepresented minorities, were invited to speak in those meetings.

2, The PI has been co-organizing the applied analysis seminar in LSU mathematics department since 2016.  The participants, graduate students and postdocs, have chances to build connections with experts and learn  about new mathematics in the field of analysis and PDEs. The seminar is drawing the students' interest to study PDEs.

3, The PI has taught a graduate course on PDEs in 2017 and a topic course on PDEs and spectral geometry in 2018. 

4, The PI worked with one graduate students at JHU and is advising one undergraduate at LSU on research about ``Nodal sets of eigenfunctions on the balls''. 


Last Modified: 07/25/2019
Modified by: Jiuyi Zhu
